description: Construction of a new 2-storey sports hall comprising hall, office, storage, foyer and viewing gallery with associated tree screening
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

No development shall take place (including any works of demolition) until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:i) How the proposed development will be built;ii) Hours of working (which shall be limited to 08.00 to 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 to 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays);iii) The procedure for loading/unloading materials;iv) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;v) The protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;vi) The protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; vii) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site and whether a banksman will be provided;viii) Temporary site access;ix) Signing system for works traffic;x) Whether site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads;xi) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site;xii) The storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;xiii) The potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;xiv) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;xv) The location of all ancillary site buildings;xvi) The means of enclosure of the site, its erection and maintenance;xvii) Wheel washing equipment;xviii) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors;xix) Meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used); andxx) The method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phasesDeliveries/collections to and from the site shall use a route that is agreed with the highway authority and the agreed route shall be signed accordingly.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies T4 and T7 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS7, DM9 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.This condition must be a pre-commencement condition in order to be effective.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details and samples of the facing and relevant construction materials to be utilised in the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The details shall include the acoustic attenuation properties of the materials along with a commentary on the level of acoustic attenuation the materials would achieve on site. The development shall then be carried out in accordance with the approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development and so that noise emanating from the buildingis limited to acceptable levels, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The site and building works required to implement the development shall be only carried out between the hours of 08.00 and 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 and 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and SundaysReason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The rating level of any noise emitted from fixed plant and equipment on site shall not exceed LAr,1hour 35dB during the day and LAr,15mins 30dB at night. The noise levels shall be measured or calculated 1m externally to any window at the nearest residential facade. Measurements and assessments shall be made according to British Standard BS4142:2014Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D14 of the London Plan 2021 policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of the development a Construction Method Statement shall be submitted to and agreed by the Local Planning Authority outlining measures that will be taken to control dust, noise and other environmental impacts of the development.Reason: To ensure that risks noise, dust and pollution  are minimised, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to commencement of groundworks (excluding site investigations and demolition), the applicant must submit a fullFlood Risk Assessment and detailed drainage design, including drawings, supporting calculations and Drainage Assessment Form to the Lead Local Flood Authority for review and approval, aligned with the Tiffin Girls' School Flood Risk Statement (27 November 2020) and the Outline Drainage Strategy (27 November 2020) and associated drawings. A detailed management plan confirming routine maintenance tasks for all drainage components must also be submitted to demonstrate how the drainage system is to be maintained for the lifetime of the development.Reason: To prevent the risk of flooding to and from the site in accordance with relevant policy requirements including but not limited to London Plan Policy SI 13, its associated Sustainable Design and Construction SPG, the Non-StatutoryTechnical Standards for Sustainable Drainage Systems and Kingston Council's Local Plan Policy DM4.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance the recommendations and findings of the ASL Report 297-20-494-09 Rev1 Site Investigation - New Gym Building, Tiffin Girls School, published December 2020). The approved measures shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: To ensure that risks from land contamination are minimised, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

In the event at any time when carrying out the approved development that contamination is found that was not previously identified, it must be reported in writing immediately to the Local Planning Authority. An investigation and risk assessment must be undertaken in respect of this contamination and where remediation is necessary a remediation scheme must be prepared and implemented upon approval of the Local Planning Authority.In the event of a proposal change and inclusion of soft landscaping then a suitable cover layer and validation scheme in accordance with 'British Research Establishment (2004) Cover Systems for Land Regeneration: Thickness Design of Cover Systems for Contaminated Land' must be prepared and implemented upon approval of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure that risks from land contamination are minimised, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to any above ground level works,  a community use agreement prepared in consultation with Sport England shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority in consultation with the Chair of the DevelopmentControl Committee.  The agreement shall apply to double height sports hall hereby approved, and include details of pricing policy, hours of use, access by non-educational establishment users, management responsibilities and a mechanism for review. The development shall not be used otherwise than in strict compliance with the approved agreement.Reason: To secure well managed safe community access to the sports facility/facilities, to ensure sufficient benefit to the development of sport and to accord with Core Strategy Policy Policy DM23.

Prior to the occupation of the Sports Hall hereby permitted an External Lighting Strategy shall be submitted in writing for approval by the local planning authority  in consultation with the Chair of the Development Control Committee. The lighting shall only be installed in accordance with the approved strategy and thereafter operated in accordance with the strategy. Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The sports hall hereby approved shall not be used for the purposes hereby permitted before 06:30 or after 21:30 daily. Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Within 3 months of commencement of development, full details the  landscaping scheme including  planting of 7 new trees along the boundary of the site, adjacent to the sports hall hereby approved, to include species and size at planting,  shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.  Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.  Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Within 3 months of commencement of development,  a scheme to enhance the nature conservation interest of the site shall  besubmitted to and agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The scheme shall be implemented in full prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved.Reason: To safeguard and protect the sites bio diversity and nature conservation value in accordance with Policy DM6 (Biodiversity) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved the improvement in CO2 emissions as set out in the Energy Strategy Desco (Design & Consultancy) Ltd 30/11/2020 to achieve 65% carbon savings using SAP10 methodology and that the development has achieved at least the BREEAM excellent standard for the 'Wat 01' water category shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy SI2 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012

Inspection: Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment: The works proposed are acceptable.  Recommendation: No objections.

Reasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans/documents submitted for the purposes of this application are consistent with the parent planning permission reference 20/02942/FUL, however, any inconsistencies would be resolved in favour of the parent permission. An Application for Approval of Details Reserved by Condition should not be used to evolve or modify the scheme in a way that is substantially different from that set out in the application.

Application Site: The application relates to an approximately 0.27ha site to the rear of Sunnyfarm located to the south-east of Green Lane. The site comprises a large single-storey building.  The site benefits from an existing vehicular access point to the side of Sunnyfarm. The site is adjoined by residential dwellings to the east and west and a field/garden area to the south-west.The site is located within designated Green Belt land. There is a woodland area Tree Protection Order to the west of the site between the site and Bonesgate Stream which is a Site of Importance for Nature Conservation (SINC). There are no Tree Protection Orders (TPO) on the site. The site has a PTAL rating of 0 on a scale of 0-6b with 6b being the most accessible, meaning it has a very low public transport accessibility.  There are bus stops for bus routes 71, 467 and N65, which are located approximately 650m away and 10 minutes walk from the site, along Garrison Lane. Chessington South train station is also within a 10-minute walk from the site. Green Lane is a local unclassified road. The site is not within a controlled parking zone (CPZ). Proposal: The proposal is the change of use from an industrial to residential unit with associated works, including the installation of solar panels. Relevant History: 1219/S: Continued use for light industrial purposes. Granted 09.05.1982. Consultation: A total of 4 neighbouring properties were consulted and no representations were received. Consultees: Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer: no objection, subject to conditions.Tree and Landscape Officer: no objections. Planning Considerations: The key areas of assessment are:- Principle of Development - Character and Design - Housing Mix- Standard of Accommodation - Impact on Residential Amenity- Highways and Transportation- Biodiversity, Trees and Landscaping- Climate Change and Sustainability - Fire SafetyPrinciple of Development: The 2 main components to consider for the principle of development are 1) impacts on the Green Belt; 2) loss of employment floorspace; 3) new residential use. 1) Impacts on Green Belt:National Planning Policy Framework 2024 (NPPF) at Paragraph 154 states "development in the Green Belt is inappropriate." Paragraph 152 of the NPPF states that "inappropriate development is, by definition, harmful to the Green Belt and should not be approved except in very special circumstances." "Very special circumstances' will not exist unless the potential harm to the Green Belt by reason of inappropriateness, and any other harm resulting from the proposal, is clearly outweighed by other considerations." This is echoed in London Plan 2021 (LP) Policy G2 and LDF Core Strategy 2012 (CS) Policy DM5. Paragraph 154 of the NPPF states there are exceptions to buildings being regarded as inappropriate in the Green Belt. The applicant has argued exemption (h)(iv) is most relevant to the proposal. Exception (h)(iv) states development may be appropriate within the Green Belt if it involves the "the re-use of buildings provided that the buildings are of permanent and substantial construction" and the development preserves the openness of the Green Belt and does not conflict with the purposes of including land within it. RBK's Green Belt and Metropolitan Open Land Assessment 2018 (GBMOLA) identifies the site as falling within GB1 and making a 'significant contribution' to the Green Belt. The Planning Practice Guidance (PPG) (Paragraph: 001 Reference ID: 64-001-20190722) states the openness of the Green Belt involves the following aspects: 1) spatial aspects; 2) visual aspects; 3) duration of development; 4) degree of activity, including traffic generation. In terms of spatial and visual aspects, the proposal would involve the re-use of the existing building therefore, no new structures or buildings would be introduced on the site. Additional landscaping and 2 car parking spaces and cycle parking would be introduced to support the new residential use. This would be an improvement to the lawful use of the site for vehicle maintenance and repair where multiple vehicles were accessing the site and parked for maintenance. Officers consider the proposed development would result in an improvement of the site compared to the existing lawful use and would preserve the openness of the Green Belt in compliance with NPPF Paragraph 154. 2) Loss of employment floorspace: NPPF at para 85 states planning decisions should help create the conditions in which businesses can invest, expand and adapt. Significant weight should be placed on the need to support economic growth and productivity, taking into account both local business needs and wider opportunities for development.LP Policy E4 states that a sufficient supply of land and premises must be provided and maintained in different parts of London to meet current and future demands for industrial and related functions. CS Policy DM17 acts to protect existing employment land and premises to meet business needs and provide employment.  The policy is clear that alternative uses will not be acceptable unless it has been demonstrated by sound evidence and rigorous marketing over a number of years (up to two years) that there is no quantitative or qualitative need for a range of employment uses. The Applicant claims the building was formally used for commercial vehicle repairs but this use has long ceased and has been used for domestic storage associated with the adjoining dwelling at Sunnyfarm for several years. Officers confirm the existing lawful use of the building is for light industrial uses (Use Class E) as granted by planning permission in 1982 under 1219/S. CS Policy DM17 is clear in protecting employment premises. The Applicant claims that there would be no loss of employment as the site does not currently contribute to employment locally. Irrespective of the premises not currently being used for light industrial uses, no supporting information in the form of marketing evidence has been provided to justify the loss of the employment floorspace and demonstrate the site could not be brought back into a commercially viable premises. The site is in a sustainable, albeit remote, location and would be capable of supporting continued employment uses. This is evidenced by the number of operational light industrial uses in the direct vicinity of the site, including car repair workshops Unit 1 and 3 Winry Green Lane. The Kingston Employment Land Review (2022) clearly states there is an acute shortage of small light industrial uses. The loss of employment floorspace weighs heavily against the scheme and is contrary to the outcomes sought under LP Policy E4 and CS Policy DM17. 3) New residential development: LP Policy GG2 and NPPF at Paragraph 125 promote the redevelopment of underutilised land for the delivery of housing. CS Policy CS10 sets out the Borough's housing targets as defined by the LP. LP Policy H1 sets ten-year targets for net housing completions that each local planning authority should plan for. Table 4.1 sets out the 10-year targets for net housing completions in each London Borough from 2019/20 - 2028/29). The requirement for Kingston is to deliver 9,640 homes in this 10 years period which would equate to 964 net completions per annum.The Council cannot demonstrate a 5-year supply of housing land as required by the NPPF therefore, paragraph 11 of the NPPF indicates that planning permission should be granted unless (i) the application of policies in this Framework that protect areas or assets of particular importance provides a clear reason for refusing the development proposed; or (ii) any adverse impacts of doing so significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits, when assessed against policies in this Framework taken as a whole. In other words, the tilted balance weighs a development's adverse impacts against its benefits, not on a level playing field, but tilted towards granting permission. These considerations should be given considerable weight in the assessment of any forthcoming planning application. The principle of new residential development on the site is supported as it would contribute towards the borough's housing targets. This carries weight in favour of the application. Support for the principle of development is subject to compliance with Development Plan policies.Housing Mix:The NPPF at para 63 directs that the size, type and tenure of housing needed for different groups in the community should be assessed and reflected in planning policies. CS Policy DM13 states new residential development is expected to incorporate a mix of unit sizes and types, and provide a minimum of 30% of units as 3 or more bedroom units, unless it can be robustly demonstrated that this would be unsuitable or unviable.The proposal is for a 3-bedroom, 6-person house. The proposal will deliver a family-sized dwelling in compliance with CS Policy DM13. This carries weight in favour of the proposal.Character and Design: Para 131 of the NPPF states the creation of high-quality, beautiful and sustainable buildings and places is fundamental to what the planning and development process should achieve.LP Policy D3 states that development should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions. CS Policy CS8 and DM10 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed development would retain the existing outbuilding and includes minimal external alterations, including new darkened featured metal cladding, new revised front door position on the south-west elevation and new full height windows on all elevations. Officers consider the cladding and glazing to be contemporary and high-quality. Officers confirm the proposal would preserve and enhance the character and appearance of the host property and surrounding area. This is given neutral weight in the assessment of the scheme. Standard of Accommodation: NPPF para 135 sets an expectation that new development will be designed to create places that amongst other things have a 'high standard' of amenity for existing and future users.LP Policy D6 sets out the standards for new housing within London, in terms of overall GIA, built-in storage space, bedroom sizes and ceiling heights. Housing development should be of high quality design and provide adequately-sized rooms, with comfortable and functional layouts which are fit for purpose and meet the needs of Londoners without differentiating between tenures. CS Policy DM13 states that the Council will expect proposals for new residential development to demonstrate that the scheme has been designed to provide adequate internal space appropriate to the intended number of occupants. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy requires developments to ensure adequate private and/or communal amenity space.The new house would have a gross internal area of 156sqm in compliance with LP Policy D6. The double bedrooms are all 10.5sqm which is under the required 11.5sqm required floor area under LP Policy D6. The dwelling would provide an acceptable level of storage in compliance with LP Policy D6. The undersized double bedrooms would not achieve a functional and comfortable layout for future occupants. This weighs heavily on the scheme. The new house would be dual aspect and each habitable room would be serviced by at least one window for suitable ventilation, outlook and access to natural light in compliance with LP Policy D6. An Internal Daylight and Sunlight Report has been submitted which confirms the internal daylight levels would achieve the target lux levels in line with the BRE Guidelines. To protect the privacy of future occupants, condition would be secured to ensure all windows servicing bathrooms would be obscure glazed. There would be no change in the ceiling height of the property which achieves a minimum 2.5m floor-to-ceiling height for at least 75% of the GIA, in compliance with LP Policy D6. Officers consider future occupants would be provided with a suitable level of  daylight penetration, ventilation and cooling and a sense of space. The new house would have a rear garden with a minimum area of 350sqm, in compliance with CS Policy DM10 and Policy Guidance 13 and 14 of the Residential Design SPD. Officers would have secured details of the proposed boundary treatments by condition if the scheme was otherwise acceptable. The new house would be accessible from the south-east side of the building. The proposal would meet at least Building Regulation M4(2) 'accessible and adaptable dwellings' in terms of step-free access, in compliance with LP Policy D7.In summary, the proposed undersized double bedrooms in the proposed house would not achieve an acceptable standard of accommodation for future occupants, in terms of functional and comfortable layout, contrary to LP Policy D6 and CS Policy DM10. This carries moderate weight against the scheme. Impact on Residential Amenity:NPPF para 135 sets an expectation that new development will be designed to create places that amongst other things have a 'high standard' of amenity for existing and future users. This is reflected in LP Policy D3. CS Policy DM10 is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.No changes are proposed to the development footprint or structure therefore, there would be no impacts on neighbouring amenity in terms of overbearing enclosure and overshadowing. New full height windows are proposed on all elevations, except the south-west elevation. The proposed windows on the south-east elevation would face the rear garden and would not result in adverse impacts on neighbouring privacy. The building is setback appropriately 1.5m from the north and western site boundaries. Development to the north within the rear garden of the Vernette property is an outbuilding. The existing dwellinghouse at Sunnyfarm is located approximately 21m therefore, overlooking opportunities would be mitigated by the setback. The presence of boundary fencing and thick vegetation would assist in mitigating any privacy impacts.There would be no noticeable difference in coming and goings to the property however, Officers consider it would be commensurate with the residential setting of Green Lane. The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of impacts on neighbouring residential amenity. Highways and Transportation: NPPF para 116 states development should only be prevented or refused on highways grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or the residual cumulative impacts on the road network, following mitigation, would be severe. CS Policy DM10 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected. The proposal would utilise the existing driveway from Green Lane and include 2 car parking spaces in the rear garden. The number of car parks exceeds the maximum standards under LP Table 10.3 (maximum of 1.5 car parks within an Outer London PTAL 0 location) however, the Council's Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer considers it to be acceptable due to the site conditions and location. The Design and Access Statement confirms the car parking would be supported by EV charging in compliance with LP Policy T6.1(C). If the scheme was otherwise acceptable, details of these facilities would have been secured by condition. A total of 3 cycle parking spaces are proposed adjacent to the car parking area in compliance with LP Policy T5. Details of the cycle storage would be secured by condition to ensure it is weatherproof, secure and accessible in line with the London Cycle Design Standards. Waste storage is shown on the Proposed Site Plan as being located to the south of the vehicle accessway. This storage location is approximately 70m from Green Lane which significantly exceeds the required drag distances under Appendix 2 of the Residential Design Guide SPD. The Design and Access Statement states sufficient access and turn-around facilities are proposed on-site for a refuse collection vehicle however, no details have been provided. No details of the proposed waste storage capacity or collection arrangements have been provided. If the scheme was otherwise acceptable, these details would be secured by condition to ensure they comply with the required storage capacity standards and siting requirements under the Residential Design Guide SPD and CS Policy CS9. A Construction Management Plan would have been secured if the scheme was otherwise acceptable to manage impacts of construction vehicles on the local highway and is appropriately managed and there would be no adverse waste or spills that may harm the environment. Overall, Council's Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer has not objected to the proposal. The proposal would not adversely impact the local road network and would provide sufficient cycle and refuse storage facilities, subject to final details being secured by condition. This carries neutral weight in the assessment of the application. Biodiversity, Trees and Landscaping: NPPF at para 136 states trees make an important contribution to the character and quality of urban environments, and can also help mitigate and adapt to climate change. LP Policy G6 states that development proposals should manage impacts on biodiversity and aim to secure net biodiversity gain (BNG). CS Policy DM6 echoes these principles. LP Policy G7 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. CS Policy DM10 sets out that the Council expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs) are not adversely affected.The proposal would primarily involve internal changes only and will not impact priority habitat or protection/priority species therefore is exempt from securing BNG. A Bat Emergency Survey Report (dated August 2024) was submitted. The survey was carried out between 24 and 26 June 2024. The report confirms no bats were observed roosting within the building and no further surveys were required. The report recommends bat friendly lighting is installed. The recommendations of the Bat Emergency Survey Report would have been secured by condition if the scheme was otherwise acceptable. A Tree Constraints Plan, Tree Impact Assessment, Arboricultural Impact Assessment and Method Statement were submitted. No trees would be impacted by the proposed development. The information confirms no trees would be removed, pruning would be required on T7, and 3 trees would be impacted by new hard surfacing. The Council's Tree Officer has raised no objection to the proposed works. If the scheme was otherwise acceptable, the recommended tree protection methods would have been secured by condition. A high level landscaping plan has been proposed. If the scheme was otherwise acceptable, a detailed landscaping plan, including long-term management, would have been secured by condition. The proposal is acceptable in terms of ecology, tree impacts and landscaping, subject to securing final details by condition. This is a neutral matter in the assessment of the scheme. Climate Change and Sustainability: NPPF at para 161 sets an expectation that planning will support transition to a low carbon future. LP Policy SI 2 requires major development to be net zero-carbon. Although the subject application is not a major application, greenhouse gas emissions should be minimised to the greatest extent possible. CS Policy DM3 states that design proposals should incorporate climate change adaptation measures based on the type and extent of the main changes expected in the local climate throughout the lifetime of the development, this is likely to require a flexible design that can be adapted to accommodate the changing climate, e.g. provision of additional shading or cooling.The proposal would reuse an existing building which is supported from a sustainability perspective. PV panels would be installed on the roof which is in line with green sustainability objectives under LP Policy SI 2 and CS Policy DM3. If the proposal was otherwise acceptable, a condition requiring the proposed dwelling to achieve a mains water consumption of 105L or less per person per day would have been secured, in line with the Optional Requirement of the Building Regulations and specified in LP Policy SI 5. The proposal is supported on climate change and sustainability grounds. Fire Safety:LP Policy D12 requires all developments to achieve the highest standards of fire safety. A Fire Safety Strategy has been submitted that demonstrates the proposal would provide a suitable means of emergency escape and be fitted with passive and active fire safety measures. The proposed dead-end accessway to the new house is approximately 70m long however, sufficient turning space is provided at the head of the driveway for fire-fighting vehicles in compliance with Requirement B5 of Approved Document B. Officers consider the highest standard of fire safety has been achieved on the site in compliance with LP Policy D12. If the scheme was otherwise acceptable, the Fire Safety Strategy would  have been secured by condition. This is given neutral weight in the assessment.Conclusion and Planning Balance:This application has been considered in the light of policies set out in the development plan and other material considerations. The proposed development would result in an improvement of the site compared to the existing lawful light industrial use and would preserve the openness of the Green Belt in compliance with NPPF Paragraph 154. This carries positive weight in favour of the application. It is noted that the Council does not have a 5-year housing supply. The proposed development would provide a new dwellinghouse and would make a small but positive contribution towards the Borough's housing supply. This is afforded weight in favour of the proposal. No sound evidence or rigorous marketing has been submitted to justify there is no quantitative or qualitative need for the employment floorspace. The site could continue to operate as a commercially viable premises which is evidenced by the number of successful Class E Uses within direct vicinity of the site. The loss of employment floorspace is contrary to LP Policy E4 and CS Policy DM17 and carries significant weight against the scheme. The new dwelling would include undersized double bedrooms resulting in a dysfunctional internal layout and poorly designed home for future occupants, contrary to LP Policy D6 and CS Policy DM10. This weighs heavily against the scheme.Impacts on residential neighbouring amenity, car parking, cycle and waste storage and collection, ecology, trees and landscaping, climate change and sustainability, and fire safety are neutral matters which could have been appropriately managed by securing final details via conditions. Officers have taken into account the Housing Delivery Test tilted presumption in favour of development as set out in para 11 of the NPPF whilst considering the conflicts with the Development Scheme. For this scheme, the adverse impacts of the development would significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits, when assessed against the policies in the NPPF taken as a whole. As such, Officers recommend planning permission be refused.

IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2022 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe site comprises a  ground floor commercial unit and is located in the designated Kingston Old Town Conservation Area, a designated heritage asset. It is also located adjacent to  2 High Street, locally listed building (non designated heritage asset)  and opposite  Guildhall, Grade 2 listed building  (designated heritage asset) and within close proximity of Clattern Bridge, Grade 2 listed (designated heritage asset).  In addition, the site is also  within  :Area of Archaeological Significance 1.1 Kingston Core, Area of Archaeological Significance 2.2 Kingston Town, Article 4  KingstonArticle 4 Kingston town centreFlood Zone 2, 3 and 3bThames Side Strategic Area of Special CharacterThames Policy Area Riverside Strategy Consultation Neighbour consultation - 14 notified, no responseKTCAAC - objection. This a retrospective application because the delivery window has been in use for several weeks. It is an inappropriate addition to this sensitive location which is adjacent to the Grade 1 listed Clattern bridge and Grade 2 listed Guildhall as well as numerous locally listed assets. It follows PA 24/02633 for signage from the same applicant  which we objected to & has been refused by officers.Highways - objection. The site has a PTAL of 6a, which indicated  an excellent level of public transport accessibility and a bus stop is located outside the site, which serves bus routes 85, 371, 458, 465, 515, 715, K1, K4, 513/514, respectively. The listed number of bus services going through the above mentioned bus stop provides an indication of the very busy nature of the public footway outside the site building and High Street, in general.The proposed alteration of the existing glass panel and its replacement with a glazed open swing window to allow for delivery access, would obstruct the safe use of the public footway by pedestrians and commuters, who are waiting to board the respective bus services at the above mentioned bus stop. As such the proposal is considered unacceptable and goes contrary to Policy T2 - Healthy Streets of the London Plan 2021. Planning HistoryThe application site has been the subject of  numerous  planning applications for alterations to the shopfront and the display of advertisements. The most recent  planning history is set out below.24/02633/ADV - Installation of 2nos internally illuminated fascia signs and 2nos internally illuminated projecting signs. Refused 19.12.2415/013007/ADV - Display of 2 externally illuminated fascia signs and 2 externally illuminated projected signs. Granted 07.12.1514/013325/FUL - Alterations to external elevations of nos 2-6 High Street. GRanted 17.08.1514/12858/FUL Replacement of 2 x existing shop fronts to form 1 x new shop front. Granted 01.10.1414/12520/FUL - Change of use of ground and first floors to A3 (restaurant) use, with associated ventilation ducting. Granted 27.10.14882218 - Display of externally illuminated fascia sign. Granted 06.04.89882125 - Display of externally illuminated fascia sign. Granted 07.02.89ProposalAlteration to shop front  with new delivery collection window, decoration and signage as stated on the validation letter. In determining this planning application, Officers have solely assessed and duly  determined the proposed alteration to the shopfront of this ground floor commercial unit .This is on the basis that Officers note that the proposed signage as shown on the submitted drawings  replicates the signage  proposal which was presented  within the recent submission for an application  consent to display advertisement application  24/02633/ADV which was refused on 19.12.24.  The Officer's decision on this matter  (proposed signage) would not be indifferent  to the issued decision for 24/02633/ADV and has therefore  the signage elements been excluded from  the description of proposed works for the determination of this application. Planning Assessment The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Impact on Heritage Assets- Fire Safety DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The submitted application drawings identify the proposed works as follows subject to this application : - Existing glazing to be replaced with fixed glazed panel and inward opening hinged rider collection window. Framing painted to match shopfront - New glazed window panel.Within the supportive Planning Design and Access Statement and the separate Heritage Design Access statement , the description of proposed works is as follows :'The proposed works to the shopfront exterior would  comprise a complete made good and repainting of the existing timber shopfront, stall riser and pilasters.   Made good and repaint existing fascia (and new illuminated signage. New projecting and fascia signs. Menu signage and pendant signage behind the existing glass - RBK not determining these works as part of the application). Alteration to existing glass panel to the RHS to replace with glazed open swing window to allow for delivery access'. Officers note an inconsistency between the submitted drawings and the illustrative drawing of the proposed altered shopfront in the Planning Design and Access Statement and separate Heritage Design Access Statement  with regard to the details of the proposed delivery collection  window in terms of the size and number of glazed panels. At the time of writing this Officer Report, it is noted that  works have been carried out  to alter the shopfront of the identified ground floor commercial unit  at 4-6 High Street  in the absence of a planning decision.None of these works correlate with the identified proposed works  as set out in this planning application.   The applicant would  therefore be advised to submit a separate planning application relating to the implemented works for determination  by the Local Planning Authority. Based on the submitted plans  under planning application 24/02632/FUL for the alterations to the shopfront, Officers have considered the proposal in the context of RBK Supplementary Planning Guidance (SPG) 'Shopfronts and Shop Sign Design Guide'  2005.   Page 7  Design Approach stipulates that 'A statement should be submitted that makes a logical case in support of the application'.  The SPG  Design Approach continues by stating  'Any alterations or new shopfronts should be considered in the context of the wider streetscene. Elements should relate to one another in terms of scale and location. The relationship between individual properties can contribute to an overall character, which creates an environment attractive to shoppers.'Section 3 of the SPG sets out the General Shopfront Principles that states that '(v) the scale and proportion and profile of window frames, glazing bars and door locations should be derived from the characteristics of the street and the architectural style of the upper floors.'  Under  Section 3.1  Specific shopfront principles B Window frame and door principles  (27), the SPG stipulates  that 'Glazing should always be transparent, even in non retail units. Opaque, frosted, reflective, mirrored or tinted glass is normally unacceptable, unless it has a functional use in small selective areas.  Shatterproof safety glass (laminated glass) should be used to ensure public safety  and as a security measure'.Should Officers be minded to approve  this planning application,  planning conditions  would be   attached to the  planning decision requiring  the inward opening hinged rider collection window as shown on the submitted drawings to be inward opening only and the new glazed window panel  to the far right of the shopfront would be transparent  glazed.In the context of the  existing shopfront,  whilst the proposed alterations would alter the proportionality and appearance of the far right hand side of the shopfront in terms of the glazed panel arrangement , it is considered  that the proposal is unlikely to have a detrimental harmful impact on the  overall character and appearance of the shopfront and  would preserve the overall character and appearance of the surrounding area which forms part of the  Old Kingston Town Conservation Area. Impact on Heritage Assets  Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 202 to 221 of the NPPF 2024 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, Paragraph 207 states that great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be), irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance. The building occupies a prominent position in the street scene, adjacent to a locally listed building (2 High Street)  and opposite Guildhall, Grade 2 listed building  (designated heritage asset) and within close proximity of Clattern Bridge, Grade 1 listed (designated heritage asset).  It also resides within Kingston Old Town Conservation Area (designated heritage asset).In light of the above  character and design assessment,  overall, it is considered that the proposed change would have a negligible impact on the character and appearance of the host building. The harm identified would not be considered to be less than substantial harm  and the proposal deemed acceptable.  Within the context of the existing building, it is considered that the proposed alteration to the shopfront would not result in less than substantial  harm to the significance of the Kingston Old Town Conservation  Area.Impact on HighwaysThe proposed alterations to the shopfront includes the replacement of the existing glazing with a fixed glazed panel and inward opening hinged rider collection window .   An objection has been received from RBK Highways  raising concern  that the installation of the delivery collection window and its operation would  obstruct the safe use of the public footway by pedestrians and commuters within its vicinity. Officers note the  width of the existing public footway within the close vicinity of the proposed  delivery collection window is  unduly narrow. The applicant has not  submitted  any acceptable  mitigation details  for Officers to review  in terms of how the delivery collections would operate both in terms of drivers waiting for collections on the public footway and the parking of vehicles particularly at peak times  in order to not obstruct the safe use of the public footway.RBK Highways conclude that the proposal for alterations to the shop front would be unacceptable and would be contrary to Policy T2 - Healthy Streets of the London Plan 2021. RBK Officers  endorse this conclusion.  Conclusion In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

It is proposed that the outbuilding would be used for purposes incidental or ancillary to the primary use of the main dwelling house. Officers are concerned that the size and layout of the proposed outbuilding have the appearance of a self contained unit and there are all the primary functions of a self contained dwelling present kitchen, living room, separate bedroom and bathroom. In addition to this the outbuilding would have an independent access via the rear access road and gate. The size of the rear garden and the layout of the site is such that given the access to the rearthe plot could easily be subdivided.  Officers have considered whether the use of a condition would restrict the possibility of the outbuilding being used independent of the main dwelling and conclude a condition would not be fit for purpose in this instance given the above points. On balance it is considered that the proposal would tip the scales of what is considered to be incidental/ancillary to the primary use of the site a single dwelling house and that the proposal would not be ancillary or incidental to the primary use of the site a dwellinghouse. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to not be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than not in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way. The new proposaApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalConversion of garage to habitable room with changed to fenestrations. Erection of single storey rear and first floor side extensions, erection of rear dormer roof extension with installation of 3nos. front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion and all associated worksConsultation7 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire safety.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Officers note the current flat roofed element of the existing property that appears to have been permitted circa 1979. The proposed hipped roof extension to accommodate the proposed rear dormer is of a poor design and would be discordant when viewed within the streetscene. This, combined with the existing flat roofed area would be jarring and would not respect the character of the existing dwelling or the wider area  The proposed development is therefore considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be an adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy. Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Erection of a single storey side extension with associated landscaping. Replacement of existing rear patio door.Consultations14 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey side extension would be set back from the front elevation by approximately 4.2m, the proposed front elevation would be made of brick similar to the existing one, it would have a solder brick course and reconstituted stone lintel/canopy. As such the proposal would appear in keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area when viewed from Chatnam Road, there would be no significant impact on the existing street scene as a result of the proposal.The proposed extension would  gradually increase its height to approximately 4m and width towards the rear. It is acknowledged that the proposed total height of the extension featuring a flat roof would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 35, however considering the proposed design, scale and siting it is considered to be acceptable in this case.The elements of the flat roof would not be directly visible with Chatnam Road. The proposed timber cladding and aluminium framed glazing system would appear as a modern extension to a traditional dwelling. The proposed mass and bulk of the proposal due to its siting, is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. Officers note the existing two storey side extension at the adjoining property No 56 Chatham Road, planning permission ref no 92/0046/FUL. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The proposal would pass the 45 degree rule in relation to the nearest habitable openings at the adjoining property No 56. As such, it is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Planning Fire Statement, which is considered to be acceptable.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
